conclusion: The suitcase has a mass of 15 kg and is pulled with a force making an angle θ above the horizontal. The gravitational acceleration is g = 10 m/s², and the resistance is proportional to the supporting force of the ground with a ratio μ.

premise: Weight: mg (downwards), Normal reaction of the floor: N (upwards), Pulling force: F; horizontal component F cos θ, vertical component F sin θ (upwards), Kinetic friction: f = μN, acting horizontally opposite the motion.
conclusion: Vertical equilibrium: N + F sin θ = mg ⇒ N = mg – F sin θ

premise: Horizontal equilibrium: Forward pull = backward friction, F cos θ = μN
conclusion: Insert vertical equilibrium into horizontal equilibrium: F cos θ = μ (mg – F sin θ)

premise: F cos θ = μ (mg – F sin θ)
conclusion: Collect F–terms on the left: F (cos θ + μ sin θ) = μmg

premise: F (cos θ + μ sin θ) = μmg
conclusion: For any given θ, the pull required is F(θ) = μmg / (cos θ + μ sin θ)

premise: F will be minimum when the denominator D(θ) = cos θ + μ sin θ is maximum.
conclusion: Differentiate D(θ): dD/dθ = –sin θ + μ cos θ
Set to zero: –sin θ + μ cos θ = 0 ⇒ μ cos θ = sin θ ⇒ tan θ = μ
At this angle, cos θ = 1/√(1 + μ²), sin θ = μ/√(1 + μ²)

premise: cos θ = 1/√(1 + μ²), sin θ = μ/√(1 + μ²)
conclusion: D_max = cos θ + μ sin θ = √(1 + μ²)
Insert into pull equation: F_min = μmg / √(1 + μ²)

premise: F_min = μmg / √(1 + μ²), m = 15 kg, g = 10 m/s² ⇒ mg = 150 N, F_min = 90 N
